Title: Plant neighbors differentially alter a focal species' biotic interactions through changes to resource allocation
Abstract: Abstract Plant resource allocation strategies are thought to be largely a consequence of changing abiotic conditions and evolutionary history. However, biotic interactions also influence how a plant allocates resources. As a result, plants mediate indirect interactions between organisms above‐ and belowground through resource allocation. Neighboring plants can influence plant fitness directly through competition for resources, and indirectly by altering associated community interactions (associational effects), such as pollination, herbivory, and a suite of belowground interactions. Given the importance of community interactions for plant success, and the known ability for plant neighbors to change these interactions, the goal of this “pandemic project” was to understand how heterospecific plant neighbors alter plant resource allocation, whether this occurred through above‐ or belowground mechanisms, and whether this in turn alters biotic interactions and the relationship between a focal plant and its herbivore and soil community interactions. To do so, we established a common garden experiment, manipulating plant neighbor identity and the extent of interaction among neighbors (aboveground only, vs. above‐ and belowground interactions, using customized pot types), and measured changes to a focal plant and its biotic interactions over two growing seasons. We found evidence of both neighbor effects and pot type, showing that neighbor interactions affect a focal plant through both above‐ and belowground processes, and how the focal plant is affected depends on neighbor identity. Though neighbors did not directly alter herbivory or most soil microbial interactions, they did alter the relationship between belowground microbial communities and a plant response trait (specific leaf area). Plant resource allocation responses were reduced with time, showing the importance of extending experiments beyond a single growing season, and are an important consideration when making predictions about plant responses to changing conditions. This study contributes to a growing body of work showing how community contexts affect the above‐ and belowground interactions of a plant through plant resource allocation strategies.

Title: Toward “Rules” for Studying Biological Invasions
Abstract: Biological invasions are a key facet of global change, with documented rates of establishment of nonnative species rising exponentially over the last several decades across most taxa and all biological realms (Essl et al. 2011). This redistribution of the Earth's biodiversity has caused substantial health and economic harm to human societies and will affect current and future ecological and evolutionary dynamics. The field of invasion science has grown in relevance and purview as a result (Lockwood et al. 2013). This growth has mirrored that observed in environmental biology as a whole in terms of the variety of approaches employed, including laboratory experiments, smaller-scale field experiments, long-term field experiments, computational modeling, and the assembly and analysis of observational "big data" sets gathered across multiple temporal and spatial scales. However, integrating these scientific approaches and their inherent spatial and temporal scales has proven challenging. In particular, invasion scientists have struggled to identify a coherent definition, measurement schema, and theory behind nonnative invasive species impacts (Blackburn et al. 2014, Jeschke et al. 2014). Species must cross distinct stages, or barriers, before they reach the last stage of this process and earn the moniker of "invasive" (Blackburn et al. 2014). Invasive species thus are those that are well established and often increasing in population size and realize some geographical range expansion. Because they are widespread and abundant, invasive species tend also to impose major ecological effects on co-occurring native populations, communities of native species, or the entire native ecosystem (Lockwood et al. 2013). These effects can be positive, negative, or both and may affect factors that human society values, or they may not (Jeschke et al. 2014). When these effects are considered notably detrimental to ecosystems, they are often labeled as negative impacts, with a recent move to also label effects that are considered to have positive benefits to species or people as positive impacts. A primary barrier to developing invasive species' impact theories is that they integrate biological mechanisms that span from individuals up to whole ecosystems and can thus be emergent and complex outcomes of how individual organisms interact with each other and their environment. Specific invasions are often idiosyncratic and thus must be studied in detail (Elliott-Graves 2016). Recognizing that any "rules" associated with biological invasions are inductively derived and have many possible exceptions, we organized a week-long workshop to explore approaches to explain and predict invasive species' impacts. The workshop, funded by the National Science Foundation Rules of Life initiative, took place on May 2019 at the Alton Jones Campus of the University of Rhode Island. Participants were intentionally chosen from a range of scientific backgrounds in order to ensure neglected aspects of biological invasions are included. This effort resulted in the majority of participating scientists not having invasions as their primary research focus (Fig. 1). We took a broad, multidisciplinary approach by bringing together population and community ecologists with physiologists and data scientists to explore how organisms respond and adapt to dynamic and stressful environments, which is a hallmark of invasive species. We sought to identify novel approaches to the analysis of invasive species' evolutionary adaptation, range expansion, and ecological impacts through the explicit recognition of a fundamental link between an organism's physiology and its environment and how this relationship varies through space and time (Chown 2012, Lennox et al. 2015). Ultimately, by continuing to work with the participants post-workshop, our goal is to advance a coherent physiological ecology theory that can integrate across biological, spatial, and temporal scales of invasions to inform future research approaches. Here, we define physiology to include, for both plants and animals, the functions and processes that occur at the level of individual organisms and that manifest through an organism's interaction with its biotic and abiotic environment. This definition includes a variety of fundamental biological processes such as mechanisms of nutrient, water, and energy acquisition; thermoregulation and responses to extreme conditions; behavioral and hormonal responses to environmental stress; and the timing of critical life history events. These physiological processes underpin the ability of invasive species to survive sub-optimal conditions and their propensity to evolve in the face of environmental stress, which in turn dictate the likelihood that an invasive species will reach an abundance and range size likely to cause ecological impacts (Funk 2013, Behrens et al. 2017). Although these insights have previously received some attention in invasion science (Lennox et al. 2015), they have not yet coalesced into a coherent research agenda within the field. The allied approach of conservation physiology (Cooke et al. 2013, Madlinger et al. 2016) touches on aspects of invasion biology but (as yet) has not fully addressed the insights that a physiological approach to invasion science can offer (Lennox et al. 2015). Our primary thesis is that the range expansion and ecological impacts of invasive species can be profitably approached as a problem of ecological and physiological integration across biological scales from individuals up to ecosystems and landscapes. Below we elaborate on the three related approaches to exploring biological, spatial, and temporal scales that were our focus for this workshop: mechanistic physiological models of invasive species distributions, the physiological basis of invasive species ecological impacts, and insights resulting from data integration that allows research on biological integration. Predicting the spread and ultimate range limits (as well as possible impacts) of invasive species is both an interesting scientific challenge and an important prerequisite for developing effective responses and wisely allocating resources to managing invasions. There is a growing need to predict the geographical range potential and spread rates of invasive species, as such estimates provide a basis for risk assessment, population management, and identification and mitigation of impacts (Jeschke and Strayer 2008, Grayson and Johnson 2018). Species distribution models (SDMs), also known as environmental niche models (ENMs), have been used since well before the inception of modern invasion science (Gjullin 1931) to forecast the potential spread of nonnative species; reviews abound (Elith and Leathwick 2009, Merow et al. 2014a). Because of the ready availability of a variety of such models and the increasing accessibility of native range data plus environmental data layers and GIS platforms, use of these models has increased dramatically and dominates this area of invasion science. Although such models can give a rough, broad-brush picture of a species' ultimate spread, predictions can err in both directions. Species distribution models can fail to indicate a region that becomes invaded or indicate an invasion where none has (yet) occurred. Combined, these errors leave SDMs capable of predicting at a very large scale, at least over large regions, but they cannot yield accurate predictions at more local levels. One response has been to use a consensus method—that is, to use a variety of SDMs (e.g., generalized additive models, generalized linear models, bioclimatic envelope models, maximum entropy, boosted regression trees) and view the region of overlap of their predictions as the predicted ultimate distribution (Bertelsmeier et al. 2015). However, the various methods all come with assumptions and limitations, and they tend to share certain shortcomings including the failure to account for genetic variation, difficulty in accommodating data on coexisting species, difficulty in dealing with the frequent absence of absence data, and absence in the native range of certain combinations of environmental features accessible in the introduced range (Jeschke and Strayer 2008, Merow et al. 2014a). It is thus unclear that a consensus of similarly limited models substantially increases prediction accuracy. A promising approach to predicting eventual range of an invasive species is a mechanistic one, based directly on experiments on the physiology and life history of the species in question. Physiological and trait-based mechanisms have been used to predict species' range shifts and new ecological interactions within the broader field of global change biology (Sorte et al. 2010). However, these approaches have seen little use within invasion science, although an illustrative example comes from Chapman et al. (2014), who predicted the nonnative range of ragweed based on its observed response to temperature and day length. Such experiments are often time-consuming and require detailed knowledge of the species in question, which is probably the main reason their use is minimal in comparison with use of SDMs; in fact, physiological aspects of invasions are generally not often invoked (Lennox et al. 2015), probably for the same reason. Several researchers have suggested shortcuts, in which one does not study the precise physiological mechanism(s) underpinning a range limit or population size, but a shortcut is employed entailing a response of the organism that integrates physiological responses, such as knockdown times (Jørgensen et al. 2019) or thermal performance curves (Sinclair et al. 2016). Judicious use of such a mechanistic approach can yield a much more accurate prediction of the likelihood of an invasion at a smaller scale than an SDM. In addition, an SDM can be combined with mechanistic research to elucidate aspects of the ecology and evolution of invasive species, as with the demonstration of a niche shift in the new range of an invasive mite (Hill et al. 2013). Mechanistic modeling of invasive species' geographical range dynamics can also be readily combined with demographic data to generate integral projection models that are likely to yield more accurate and more detailed, small-scale predictions than SDMs alone (Merow et al. 2014b, Behrens et al. 2017). Interaction between the many users of SDMs and scientists producing mechanistic models using physiological and demographic data is rare, although such an interaction could potentially be of great use in validating SDM predictions and especially fine-tuning them to more local scales. Probably the dearth of such collaborations, and related scientific products, arises because scientists employing the different approaches publish in different journals, go to different meetings, do not interact substantially on other projects, and have not often considered the possible benefits of such collaborations. We asked how SDM/ENM approaches in invasion ecology can motivate and be integrated with physiological research to provide a mechanistic understanding of the projected spread and limits of invasive species. The ecological impacts of invasive species on native populations, communities, and ecosystems are one of the principal motivations behind studying nonnative species (Ricciardi et al. 2013, 2017). Yet, when, where, and how such impacts occur has at times proven difficult to establish. One reason for this difficulty is that when invasive species interact with other organisms and the environment, the subsequent impacts of those interactions likely vary over large spatial scales, but this variation is rarely measured. Instead, results from a few sites or a single region are often extrapolated across multiple regions, a continent, or even globally. Likewise, environmental change is currently altering climatic regimes and species are experiencing new environmental conditions in situ and responding variably over time according to prevalent local conditions. Another challenge is the perception that impacts can most usefully be measured as declines in native species' populations or loss of native species from local ecosystems. However, several or even most impacts are likely mediated through physiological mechanisms such as stress responses to perceived predation threats by invasive predators (Preisser and Bolnick 2008), reductions in food resources in the presence of invasive competitors (Lennox et al. 2015), and changes in energetic demands triggered by invasion-mediated alterations of an organism's physical environment (increased shade, denser vegetation, increasing salinity; e.g., Funk 2013, Mozdzer and Caplan 2018). These stress responses precede population declines in many instances, potentially providing a way to assess the impacts of invasive species mechanistically across multiple spatial and biological scales, and such responses may also provide an opportunity for managers to preemptively intervene and avoid negative impacts. The effects on physiology of change-related stressors, such as drought and increasing salinity, are also likely to vary both between and within species depending on intraspecific variation and the effects of stressors on competition and functional traits (Bertness and Callaway 1994, Johnson et al. 2008, De Frenne et al. 2014). Other unanswered questions include how novel interactions will influence invasive species physiology over space and time (Franklin et al. 2016) and whether intraspecific genetic variation at the population level in plant physiological tolerances will allow invaders to persist under the stresses of environmental change (Suda et al. 2015). For example, L. A. Meyerson et al. (unpublished manuscript) found that intraspecific genome size variation mediated plant stress tolerance via plasticity for invasive but not native Phragmites australis. Knowledge of impacts at the level of individual physiology provides a useful mechanistic basis for how impacts are produced, including how those impacts will vary across spatial environmental gradients and longer time frames. During the workshop, we explored questions related to the scale dependence of invasive species impacts, including how physiological processes mediate invasive species' ecological impacts and how these processes are influenced by spatial and temporal variability (including native and introduced ranges). We also sought to develop a framework for prediction to better inform invasion risk assessment and management, including assessing trait dissimilarity between native and invasive species as a mechanism to predict ecological impact. A central obstacle to achieving biological integration relative to predicting invasive species' impacts is the context-dependent nature of impacts. Context dependency is believed to result from spatial differences in biotic and abiotic conditions across locations that house an invasive species. It also results from temporally variable conditions within any one of these locations, or the changing abundance or phenotype of the invader itself. Prediction is difficult under context dependency as it suggests that it is unlikely that a single set of factors can be reliably used to characterize invasive species impact. The need for prediction, especially at management-relevant spatial scales, is thus acute. There have been consistent calls in the literature and as a part of various environmental summits to create invasive species impact databases (Olenin et al. 2014), with several efforts coming to fruition. These efforts to rank invasive species impacts provide some measure of information on the likely impacts of an invasive species within local environments (e.g., national parks, watersheds, estuaries), but the information available for such rankings is not granular enough in detail to produce impact predictions at smaller spatial scales. This issue leaves land managers, resource agencies, and policymakers with the dilemma of how to prioritize detection, control, and management of the increasing numbers of invasive species delivered to their doorstep each year via global trade. We sought to synthesize into a single framework existing approaches to generating context-specific predictions, and then to assess the needs, sources, and availability of the data required to for this framework to be useful. There is an enormous value sitting within existing data that can be used in this context; however, there are data availability gaps and a dearth of open-access data transformation workflows that move these data from raw to relevant. A primary objective for the workshop was to provide an overview of the availability of such data, illustrating where data gaps may be filled by strategic investment in empirical data gathering, better structuring of existing data warehousing, increasing accessibility of existing data sources, and developing data transformation technologies for use in invasive species impact predictions. Very few existing data sources allow for the collection, validation, and collation of formal and informal observations on the ecological impacts of invasive species at all locations across their geographical range and through time (c.f., Narščius et al. 2012). The ability of a database to accumulate observations of both invasive species occurrences and observed impacts is essential to its usefulness in allowing users to test integrative hypotheses about range expansion and impact. Spread and impact are not temporally or spatially static invasion phenomena but are instead emergent outcomes of how organisms respond to the range of environmental conditions they encounter. To capture these local-scale differences, a database on invasive species must be informed by local-scale moment-in-time observations and experiments and updated frequently with new observations of the same species across multiple locations, and with information on the same species at the same locations collected over time. Such a data framework will necessitate formalizing measurements of ecological impacts but will also involve full integration with existing data sources on species' occurrence (native and invasive), taxonomic identity, and climatic and environmental conditions. Participants are currently developing a comprehensive overview of the need for such a data repository, the feasibility of integrating such data within existing databases, and the currently unmet challenges facing development of such a database. Because the workshop included scientists with diverse expertise and perspectives that span biological realms, taxa, and disciplinary backgrounds, we anticipate innovative outcomes that may help to shape the future of invasion research. As a group, we hope to reach a wide audience of researchers and policymakers by exploring the intersection between eco-physiology and invasion biology, especially relative to how an interdisciplinary approach can inform fundamental questions about invasive species spread and impact; by developing SDM/ENM approaches in invasion science that can motivate and be integrated with physiological research to provide a mechanistic understanding of likely spread and limits of invasive species; by highlighting understudied mechanisms of invasions, such as physiological response impacts over multiple spatial and temporal scales under environmental change; and developing an eco-informatics statement-of-need paper aimed at state and federal agencies with invasive species mandates. In all of our subsequent efforts, we aim to provide context across large spatial scales (differing impacts of different species over space, impacts changing over time) to guide more effective and efficient management strategies. The workshop was funded by a National Science Foundation Grant to LAM, JLL and DS, NSF ROL 183968. We are grateful to all of the workshop participants for their insights, energy, and time.

Title: The Drosophila Modifier of Variegationmodulo Gene Product Binds Specific RNA Sequences at the Nucleolus and Interacts with DNA and Chromatin in a Phosphorylation-dependent Manner
Abstract: modulo belongs to the modifier of Position Effect Variegation class of Drosophila genes, suggesting a role for its product in regulating chromatin structure. Genetics assigned a second function to the gene, in protein synthesis capacity. Bifunctionality is consistent with protein localization in two distinct subnuclear compartments, chromatin and nucleolus, and with its organization in modules potentially involved in DNA and RNA binding. In this study, we examine nucleic acid interactions established by Modulo at nucleolus and chromatin and the mechanism that controls the distribution and balances the function of the protein in the two compartments. Structure/function analysis and oligomer selection/amplification experiments indicate that, in vitro, two basic terminal domains independently contact DNA without sequence specificity, whereas a central RNA Recognition Motif (RRM)-containing domain allows recognition of a novel sequence-/motif-specific RNA class. Phosphorylation moreover is shown to down-regulate DNA binding. Evidence is provided that in vivo nucleolar Modulo is highly phosphorylated and belongs to a ribonucleoprotein particle, whereas chromatin-associated protein is not modified. A functional scheme is finally proposed in which modification by phosphorylation modulates Mod subnuclear distribution and balances its function at the nucleolus and chromatin. modulo belongs to the modifier of Position Effect Variegation class of Drosophila genes, suggesting a role for its product in regulating chromatin structure. Many eukaryotic gene products elicit remarkable functional diversity, even those involved in basic cellular processes. In particular, increasing evidence indicates that a number of ribosomal proteins fulfill a second function apart from ribosome and protein synthesis (1Wool I.G. Trends Biochem. Sci. 1996; 21: 164-165Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (551) Google Scholar). Ribosome biogenesis takes place in the nucleolus where rDNA is transcribed in a large precursor RNA which is then processed by nucleotide modifications and specific cleavages into mature rRNAs that eventually assemble with ribosomal proteins into ribosomal subunits (2Mélèse T. Xue Z. Opin. Cell. Biol. 1995; 7: 319-324Crossref PubMed Scopus (240) Google Scholar,3Shaw P.J. Jordan E.G. Annu. Rev. Cell. Dev. Biol. 1995; 11: 93-121Crossref PubMed Scopus (409) Google Scholar). This process requires a number of additional factors, such as small nucleolar RNAs (snoRNA) 1The abbreviations used are: snoRNA, small nucleolar RNAs; RRM, RNA Recognition Motif; PEV, Position Effect Variegation; GST, glutathione S-transferase; SELEX, selection-amplification procedure; NS, non-selected sequence; RNP, ribonucleoprotein; dsDNA, double-stranded DNA; PAGE, polyacrylamide gel electrophoresis. and non-ribosomal nucleolar proteins. Our knowledge of nucleolar proteins is limited. However, a shared structural feature is the presence of modules thought to represent functional domains (3Shaw P.J. Jordan E.G. Annu. Rev. Cell. Dev. Biol. 1995; 11: 93-121Crossref PubMed Scopus (409) Google Scholar). Such modules include basic and acidic stretches, which possibly interact with ribosomal proteins (4Xue Z. Mélèse T. Trends Cell Biol. 1994; 4: 414-417Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (51) Google Scholar), and the so-called RNA Recognition Motif (RRM) (5Nagai K. Oubridge C. Jessen T.H. Li J. Evans P.R. Nature. 1990; 348: 515-520Crossref PubMed Scopus (551) Google Scholar), which could bind either rRNAs at different stages of maturation or snoRNAs. Ribosome biogenesis is tightly regulated in a close relationship with cell growth or differentiation. It has long been shown that changing cell culture conditions in a way that either improves the growth rate or induces a differentiation program results in enhancedversus decreased ribosome biosynthesis, respectively (6Nomura M. Sci. Am. 1984; 250: 102-114Crossref PubMed Scopus (17) Google Scholar). Moreover, mutations that disrupt gene functions necessary for ribosome assembly often result in growth defects. In yeast or mammalian cell lines, requirement for cell growth has been demonstrated for several snoRNAs (7Maxwell E.S. Fournier M.J. Annu. Rev. Biochem. 1995; 35: 897-934Crossref Scopus (545) Google Scholar) and for all the components of RNase MRP, the best characterized snoRNP (8Tollervey D. Kiss T. Curr. Opin. Cell Biol. 1997; 9: 337-342Crossref PubMed Scopus (380) Google Scholar). In Drosophila, several classes of mutations cause growth alteration during development, such as theMinute class (9Lindsley D.T. Zimm G.G. The Genome of Drosophila melanogaster. Academic Press Inc., San Diego1992: 433-441Google Scholar), widely believed to affect ribosomal protein genes (10Saeboe-Larssen S. Lyamouri M. Merriam J. Oksvold M.P. Lambertsson A. Genetics. 1998; 148: 1215-1224PubMed Google Scholar), and mini and bobbedmutations, which alter rRNA production (11Kay M.A. Jacobs-Lorena M. Genetics. 1987; 3: 347-351Scopus (54) Google Scholar). The Drosophila modulo gene (mod) has first been characterized as a dominant suppressor of Position Effect Variegation (PEV) (12Garzino V. Pereira A. Laurenti P. Graba Y. Levis R.W. Le Parco Y. Pradel J. EMBO J. 1992; 11: 4471-4479Crossref PubMed Scopus (67) Google Scholar). PEV occurs in experimental strains where genes placed close to constitutive heterochromatin are randomly turned on or off, leading to mosaic adult structures. The products of genes that modify PEV are believed to change the local chromatin structure, which leads, when they are mutated, to an increased (suppression of variegation) or a decreased (enhancement of variegation) expression of neighboring genes (13Elgin S.C. Curr. Opin. Genet. Dev. 1996; 6: 193-202Crossref PubMed Scopus (198) Google Scholar, 14Henikoff S. Bioessays. 1996; 18: 401-409Crossref PubMed Scopus (91) Google Scholar, 15Wakimoto B.T. Cell. 1998; 93: 321-324Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (187) Google Scholar, 16Zhimulev I. Adv. Genet. 1998; 37: 1-566PubMed Google Scholar). The dominant PEV suppression phenotype of mod, therefore, suggests that its product participates in the formation of multimeric protein complexes that package the DNA, promoting chromatin compaction and inactivation (12Garzino V. Pereira A. Laurenti P. Graba Y. Levis R.W. Le Parco Y. Pradel J. EMBO J. 1992; 11: 4471-4479Crossref PubMed Scopus (67) Google Scholar). We have recently reported thatmod, apart from its role in chromatin structuration, has a second cellular function and is required in nucleolus activity and protein synthesis capacity (17Perrin L. Demakova O. Fanti L. Kallenbach S. Mal'ceva N.I. Pimpinelli S. Zhimulev I. Pradel J. J. Cell Sci. 1998; 111: 2753-2761PubMed Google Scholar). First, cell clones deficient formod express phenotypic traits characteristic ofMinute mutations. Second, the protein, while actually associated to condensed chromatin and heterochromatin sites, is also abundantly found at the nucleolus. Consistent with this localization, Mod displays a modular organization which is often found in nonribosomal nucleolar proteins, including an acidic stretch, two basic regions located at both ends of the molecule, and four reiterated RRMs in the remaining core portion (18Krejci E. Garzino V. Mary C. Bennani N. Pradel J. Nucleic Acids Res. 1989; 17: 8101-8115Crossref PubMed Scopus (21) Google Scholar, 19Birney E. Kumar S. Krainer A.R. Nucleic Acids Res. 1993; 21: 5803-5816Crossref PubMed Scopus (589) Google Scholar). The goal of the investigation reported here was to gain insight into the nucleic acid interactions established by Mod at the nucleolus and chromatin and to determine the molecular mechanism that controls the distribution and balances the function of the protein in the two sub-nuclear compartments. The data show that the two basic domains independently contact DNA without sequence specificity, whereas RRMs provides a sequence-specific RNA-binding activity. We also report that nucleolar Mod is phosphorylated and associated to an RNA moiety, whereas the chromatin-bound Mod appears to be unmodified. A functional scheme is finally proposed in which modification by phosphorylation modulates Mod subnuclear distribution and balances its function at the nucleolus and chromatin. Primers used to generate by polymerase chain reaction sequences encoding the Mod variants were: 1) ACGTGGATCCGCCCAAAAGAAAGCCGTCACCG; 2) ACGTGGATCCGGCCGTATTTATGGTACTACGCAA; 3) ACGTGGATCCGAAGTGCCGCAGTTCAGTGAAGA; 4) ACGTGGATCCTCAGTTTGGCTCAATAAATATAGGGGC; and 5) ACGTGGATCCTGAAGAAGCGCCTGTAGAGAAGCC. Primers pairs (1+2), (2+3), (1+4), (3+4), and (4+5) were used to produce full-length Mod, the protein variants truncated from one or the two basic domains located at the N and C termini and RRMs, respectively. Johnson K.S. Gene (Amst.). 1988; 67: 31-40Crossref PubMed Scopus (5047) Google Scholar) and stored at −20 °C in NT2 buffer (20 mmTris-HCl, 5 mm NaCl, 1 mm EDTA, 0.1 mm phenylmethylsulfonyl fluoride, 0.05% Nonidet P-40, 10% glycerol, pH 7.5). For SDS-PAGE, proteins were fractionated on 7.5% gels and electroblotted onto nitrocellulose. Bidimensional gel analysis was performed as described in (21O'Farrell P.H. J. Biol. Chem. 1975; 250: 4007-4021Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). Development. 1996; 122: 3499-3508PubMed Google Scholar), resuspended in 30 μl/106 cells of cold RSB buffer (10 mmTris-HCl, 100 mm NaCl, 2.5 mm MgCl2, 1 mm dithiothreitol, 800 unit RNasin/ml, mixture of protease inhibitors, pH 7.4), sonicated on ice 2 × 5 s and centrifuged at 4 °C first at 14,000 × g for 10 min and then at 105 × g for 1 h. Cell. 1987; 61: 5-13Crossref PubMed Scopus (7) Google Scholar). The Mod protein was detected in 0.15 m and 0.30–0.45 m NaCl fractions only. Cell. 1987; 61: 5-13Crossref PubMed Scopus (7) Google Scholar) but in the presence of an excess of sodium pyrophosphate (10 mm) and of phosphatase inhibitors (2 mm sodium vanadate, 0.1 m sodium fluorure, 20 mm EDTA, and 20 mm EGTA). Nucleic Acids Res. 1991; 19: 4931-4936Crossref PubMed Scopus (125) Google Scholar). DNA binding assays were performed using 85 and 250 μg of nucleosoluble and chromatin-bound proteins, respectively. Polytene chromosome squashes and staining were performed as described in Clarket al. (28Clark R.F. Wagner C.R. Craig C.A. Elgin S.C. Methods Cell Biol. 1991; 35: 203-227Crossref PubMed Scopus (8) Google Scholar). Anti-mouse-fluorescein isothiocyanate-conjugated and anti rabbit-tetramethylrhodamine isothiocyanate conjugated secondary antibodies (Jackson) were used at a dilution of 1/150. Slides were examined under an Axiophot microscope (Zeiss). Mod has been previously shown to bind DNA bothin vitro and in vivo (12Garzino V. Pereira A. Laurenti P. Graba Y. Levis R.W. Le Parco Y. Pradel J. EMBO J. 1992; 11: 4471-4479Crossref PubMed Scopus (67) Google Scholar, 18Krejci E. Garzino V. Mary C. Bennani N. Pradel J. Nucleic Acids Res. 1989; 17: 8101-8115Crossref PubMed Scopus (21) Google Scholar).
